I‚Äôm not sure tax is where I want to stay after, but I‚Äôm not sure how limited my current role makes my exit opportunities so I‚Äôm looking for some general advice on post ACA jobs that I‚Äôd be able to go for, e.g management accountant, corporate finance etc.   Thank you.

title: Creating a fitness dropshipping store. Too saturated? Or is there still room for a niche?
self_text: I know dropshipping from Aliexpress has a bad reputation, but I don't quite have a new or innovating piece of exercise equipment in my head.  What I can do is bundle a set of equipment (from multiple sellers on Aliexpress) that can be for beginners. Either for weight loss, bodybuilding/powerlifting, or Yoga. Specifically, my 20+ years of knowledge is in bodybuilding/powerlifting (some olympic weightlifting), but have enough knowledge to fill in the gaps of my knowledge for other areas of fitness too. I can put up some free beginner guides on my Shopify, and provide basic / beginner (or intermediate) exercise programs (for free or for a small price).  Any thoughts on if this will be enough to differentiate? Or do I have to approach this differently?

title: I own a small tile business and sometimes me or the other owner have to purchase materials for a job. How do I account for and track getting reimbursed for the purchased materials?
self_text: For example, let's say I invoice a client $1,100. $1,000 for labor, $100 for materials (cost of materials + tax). I should only bear the tax burden for the $1,000 of labor, and I should be able to pass the $100 through to the client. So, on my invoice, I will simply label two separate lines: Labor and Materials. Then, when tax season comes along, I will only report the $1,000 as income, and I will simply treat the $100 as a reimbursement. As long as I have properly saved proof of this purchase being a material acquisition for said job, I should be good right? Am I missing something?  EDIT: I ask a simple question and people start shredding my personal decision to use software that works for me and apparently doesn't work for them. I wasn't asking for software advice, and no one has shared anything about quickbooks that I didn't already know. Thank you to the couple of people who stayed on topic.

title: Considering selling house after ~1.5 years and looking for advice
self_text: Looking for advice on whether it makes sense to sell our house after ~1.5 years  TL;DR: bought an expensive house 1.5 years ago; want to refocus life and finances towards some sort of FIRE or early retirement in 3-5 years after experiencing huge career changes that altered my general happiness and outlook; looking for advice on whether this plan makes any sense.  -‚Äì  My wife and I bought a house in early 2021. At the time, I was in a role I really enjoyed with a great (and very stable) income. I had some equity in the company I worked at that was worth a decent chunk of change in theory. We decided to splurge and got a nice house on the outskirts of the city for about $1.1M. It‚Äôs bigger and nicer than we needed, but it made sense at the time, and we could afford it. The appeal was having a home gym, game room, guest room, etc. That‚Äôs what we ended up getting and it is indeed great. The total carrying cost of the house is about $6500/month. We got it at just under 3% interest.  A lot has changed since then, and I‚Äôm not actually referring to the macro-economic environment. The company I was at ended up getting acquired literally a few months after we bought the house, whereas I (naively) thought we were years away from that event. The equity I had immediately got transformed into cash ‚Äì not as much as I was expecting, but still a nice payday. The two founders retired and I got a major promotion up into executive leadership. Shepherding the integration of the company has in many ways fallen on my shoulders, a task that has weighed me down in ways that will take me a long time to recover from.  I‚Äôm not happy in my new role under the parent organization, yet I can‚Äôt walk away because I have some golden handcuffs and it‚Äôs once-in-a-lifetime experience. I‚Äôve done this role over a year now, and I‚Äôm tired and burnt out and want a break after the golden handcuff period is up (3 more years). I find myself having a very different mindset on finances. 2 years ago, I felt like I had 10-20 years of working runway left in me. Now I find myself wanting to optimize towards either early retirement in the next 3-5 years or at least getting to a point where I can take a substantial multi-year break. The problem is this plan is not compatible with the house we have and its $6500/month carrying cost. The payout I‚Äôm going to get from the ‚Äúgolden handcuffs‚Äù is substantial, but not enough to retire early with that kind of monthly housing expense.  I‚Äôd be more than happy downsizing to something smaller and less nice if it meant I could get out of the grind in a few years. My wife has seen the effect this has all had on me and is very sympathetic and supportive too. We‚Äôve looked around and have sound some modest 2br apartments or 3br townhomes that we could rent for $2k-$3k/month ‚Äì less than half of the $6500/month we‚Äôre currently spending. Plus, of course, we wouldn‚Äôt be on the hook for maintaining a large high-end home.  Now this is where the macro environment comes in. Interest rates are now ~7%. In theory, our home has appreciated a good bit since we bought it (its current Zestimate is $1.45M, and Reddit says $1.35M). However, my sober assessment is it wouldn‚Äôt sell for anywhere near $1.45M at current interest rates. An exact replica of our house which is 5 years older did sell 1 month ago for $1.295M.  I‚Äôve contacted a realtor and asked them to get me a realistic market analysis. They think the house would sell for $1.2M-1.25M based on other comps actively on the market right now. If that‚Äôs true, it‚Äôs enough to sell the house with either no loss or a pretty minor loss. But let‚Äôs say there‚Äôs be a minor loss involved.  What I‚Äôm looking for is advice on whether any of this makes sense. Does it actually make sense to give up a 3% mortgage on this house to rent something much cheaper, even if we take a loss in doing so? Does this plan seem to support the goal of reaching some kind of early retirement state in 3-5 years?  There are alternative options:  ‚Ä¢	One alternate would be to do nothing ‚Äì stick around in the house for 3-5 years, then sell and downsize at that point into something that I could sustain in early retirement. The risk here is that the housing market could enter a major slump or even crash in that time period. Even if it stagnates and the house merely maintains its value, that‚Äôs a long time to pay $6500/month vs less than half that (even if some of that is going towards principal) considering we could invest the difference to help fund early retirement after that period. ‚Ä¢	Another alternative would be to rent the house out. I‚Äôm unsure if we‚Äôd be able to make an expensive high-end home cashflow by renting it, though. ‚Ä¢	A third alternative would be to sell and buy again, but this time buy in the $300k-$400k range. However, it‚Äôs unclear if this makes sense at today‚Äôs high interest rates.   -‚Äì  TL;DR: bought an expensive house 1.5 years ago; want to refocus life and finances towards some sort of FIRE or early retirement in 3-5 years after experiencing huge career changes that altered my general happiness and outlook; looking for advice on whether this plan makes any sense.  Thanks in advance!

title: Rent to own
self_text: I‚Äôll give a brief explanation of the deal I‚Äôm looking at. Open to questions and any opinions on the topic.   I am m(32) married with four kids renting a home in NH for 1600 plus utilities. Our lease is coming to an end and have option to sign another for the same amount. We have about i make about 40000 + around 3000 in bonus‚Äôs each year. We started a small food truck business that does about the same this year but is growing quickly. 1/2 to 2/3 of our business is cash. We have very little debt mainly credit card (4000) which we are actively paying off. At this point we don‚Äôt show a ton of income and there isn‚Äôt really a hope in the next 5 years to get a mortgage. But we recently came across a rent to own situation. A man that I met at the lumber yard I work at offered it to us. Right now the deal stays at: we rent from him for two years @ 1500/mo everything included. And he is going to foot the bill to do some upgrades while we are there. He had it on the market but banks wouldn‚Äôt finance it because there are some things that need to be finished. Mainly a section of floor/stairs that is painted plywood. The bones of the house are good and he doesn‚Äôt have a mortgage he built it himself him being in the trades. 2 acres of land 3 bedroom 2 bath, 3 car garage, tool shed and wood stove. He wants 400,000 for it which is a little steep for us. But we would avoid banks and have if to change our business model from a cash business. After the two years rental we would renegotiate our contract from rental to rent to own. Because he is fully responsible for utilities he wasn‚Äôt willing to put a portion of our rent towards paying down the price of house which I think is fair until after the two years. Thank you for taking the time to read this all input is welcome.

title: Basic rate tax payer ISA vs SIPP query?
self_text: Hi folks this is likely going to have a basic answer but when googling some differences are outlined and the summary always seems to be "just get both".  My specific query is as someone who's basic rate and will likely be until retirement..  So as I understand it the ISA isn't taxed on withdrawal, the sipp is in the same way as usual taxable income. So let's say state pension + workplace pension is already putting you into the taxable bracket, the SIPP is going to get taxed on withdrawal at 20% (bar 25% lump sum if that's decided).  In this case what is the advantage of the SIPP over the ISA? You get the tax relief but will get taxed later. Is it because the tax relief going in will allow your fund to grow larger than the same contribution into an ISA? So getting taxed on the way out is worth it?  Just trying to understand my options after filling up my LISA allowance.

title: AITA for wanting to know what my husband spends when he asked to double his allowance?
self_text: When my husband and I got married we merged finances, so that his paycheck gets deposited into our joint account and about 60% of mine goes into the same account. The other 40% of mine goes into an account that pays the mortgage and is used to make our monthly contributions to our brokerage account.  The reason we have it set up that way is I bought my apartment right when we started dating, and so I pay for it all with my earnings out of an account where I get a discount on the mortgage rate, and that‚Äôs why part of my paycheck is directly deposited into it.  When we got married my husband didn‚Äôt want to transition to joint credit cards, so we each have our own cards, and his is paid from his checking account and mine are paid from the joint account. All of our bills are paid from the joint account or via my credit cards, which are paid from the joint account. Since all of our bills (car, apartment maintenance, garage, utilities, cleaning person, etc.) and pretty much all of our joint meals, groceries, travel, discretionary spending, etc. are all paid from the joint account or on my credit cards, what I‚Äôve been doing is transferring a set amount to his checking account every month, which was an amount he said would be enough for his expenses.  I just checked his checking account though, and his credit card bills are more than the amount of the allowance I deposit every month. I asked him if he needs more, and he told me that he needs double what he is currently getting. He has access to our joint account and can use it for any spending or to take cash out at any time. I think if he wants to double the amount of spending money he‚Äôs getting it would be nice to know what he is spending it on.   AITA for wanting to know how much he is spending and on what? (I doubled the monthly transfer amount already, so it‚Äôs more a matter of curiosity, not a condition of him getting more).

title: Journal Entry help
self_text: Hello!  I'm trying to understand an "equity" account and what will happen at the end.  Here's my hypothetical situation: A vehicle (personal sedan) is GIFTED to a business (lets say a corporation), for whatever reason. As I understand, the journal entry for this would be something like:  DR Vehicle (asset) CR Capital Account (equity)  As I own and use the vehicle, I will depreciate the depreciable asset: DR Depreciation Expense (expense) CR Accumulated Depreciation (contra-asset account)  Finally, when I either sell or dispose of the vehicle: DR Cash (asset) DR Accumulated depreciation DR or CR Gain/loss on disposal CR Vehicle (asset)  My question is: what will/should happen to that "CR Capital Account (equity)" that I created when I first received the vehicle? Will it ever go away? Does it need to be reduced at some point? What's the journal entry to remove/reduce it?  A bit of a hypothetical, so please just entertain the scenario.

title: The one thing that pissed me off the most, from a first time home buyer
self_text: Closed on a house yesterday, first time purchasing/investing in real estate.  I've wanted to for years but never found the right deal or had the cash at the time to make a move.  Everything went smoothly, I really got a verryyy decent deal in today's market, got almost $11k in closing costs from seller because the inspection had about $4k in  very tiny  jobs.  Think "$100 to change this lightbulb, $200 to fix this leaky sink" shit like that that I will be taking on.  Shout-out to my realtor and mortgage broker.  I'm closing in like 18 days from going under contract, broker did an absolutely amazing job getting me everything I needed ASAP and passing off to underwriters.   Realtor did a great job negotiating on my behalf.  So, what pissed me off?  Fucking $15 fee to get a cashier's check.   It took all but 8 minutes at the bank.  I have to pay $15 to access  my  money, that the bank has been making $$$ off while it's been sitting in my account.  I'm frugal, not cheap, but definitely very frugal, and that just absolutely pissed me off.  I pleaded with the bank to waive the fee, but no luck.  All said and done $15 is nothing when you're spending a down payment on a house, just the idea of it really rubbed me the wrong way.  Super excited, long time lurker of this sub, have learned a ton doing a bunch of searches and reading advice.   Cheers for everybody who contributes.   I'm gonna go sit in my empty house and have a beer now before spending all weekend moving in ¬Ø‚Å†\‚Å†_‚Å†(‚Å†„ÉÑ‚Å†)‚Å†_‚Å†/‚Å†¬Ø

title: Some info on Caroline Ellison and SBF I found online (take it with a grain of salt )
self_text: SEC Chair Gary Gensler‚Äôs old boss at MIT was Glenn Ellison. His daughter Caroline Ellison is the CEO of FTX sister-company Alameda Research (and Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs lover apparently). The GC of FTX used to be lead counsel to Gary Gensler when he was CFTC Chair. Sam Bankman-Fried‚Äôs mother was Hilary Clinton‚Äôs lawyer. Gabe Bankman-Fried, brother to Sam (also a former Jane Street trader), is founder of ‚ÄúGuarding Against Pandemics‚Äù. He was a Legislative Correspondent for the US House of Representatives and an advisor to large political donors in the Democrat party. The family Aunt Linda Fried is a WEF member on the Global Agenda Council on Aging. The father, Joseph Bankman, is a Stanford professor who has lobbied on behalf of Hedge Fund managers before Congress before (film records exist). FTX Head of Ventures & Commercial at FTX Ventures, Amy Wu, started with the Clinton Foundation years ago. Nishad Singh FTX Director of Engineering has spent over 8 million for Dem candidates. Obama's Commodity Futures Trading Commissioner, Mark Wetjen, was the head of FTX Policy & Regulation. Chief regulatory officer of FTX is Dan Friedberg was previously a lawyer at Ultimate bet (a site where they basically cheated against players). Stuart Hoegner General Counselor at Bitfinex/Tether was previously Director of Compliance at Excapsa which was responsible for the Ultimate bet poker software.

title: Greedy when others are fearful or just plain stupid?
self_text: So we just had FTX go bankrupt, that seemingly didn't affect anything outside of the crypto market, but now we have block fi going bankrupt as well.  If that weren't enough threats of war have broken out today around 10 am pst. Now there's a potential nato meeting in the works. Who knows where that's leading to.   As selfish as this sounds to be worrying about this when others have much bigger problems, where does this leave us? The market completely stopped dead in its tracks after a morning bull run across the board and started retracting after this news.   For the guys with calls are you cutting them off tomorrow until further news breaks out? The guys with puts are you excited at the prospect of a crash?   What's the concensus, are you personally feeling greedy or fearful ?

title: Overpayments of mortgage or open a new savings account?
self_text: Just looking for some advice really as I'm not very knowledgeable when it comes to this sort of thing.  My wife (30F) and I (32M) bought our first house in May this year, and after Christmas we will hopefully be in a position where we can start making overpayments to the mortgage as all the big jobs in the house will be complete.  We're currently on a 30 year mortgage, with a loan amount of ¬£207,000 at 1.89% fixed over 3 years. Our monthly repayments are ¬£677.34/month, and we think we could still manage fine if we upped it to ¬£800/month which is about an 18% overpayment.   Aside from paying the mortgage off early are there any other benefits to doing this, or would we be better off opening some kind of savings account to gain interest on that money instead? I've seen one with Halifax offering 3.4%.

title: Need a car at the worst possible time.
self_text: Currently living in Rural NH where work is ~45 mins away on the highway. I've been driving around a beater for years now waiting for it to poop the bed. I've wanted a new car, but have been waiting as my girlfriend is currently interviewing for medical school, and I plan to follow her. We are not yet sure where she will be going. So far she is actively interviewing at large cities (where I dont want a car) and got into a rural area in colorado (where I do). She will know exactly where she will be going in March/April.  So fast forward to last Wednesday, I hit a deer on the freeway and total my car. So now Im in a weird situation where I don't want to commit to a car Im unsure if I will need in 9 months, but also need a car within the next month or so. Whats the most reasonable option both financially and practically?  Financially I'm not strained (within reason). I've been preping or this moment and have $20k in cash ready to deploy as needed. Short term leases look appealing, but sound expensive  EDIT: Photo for reference:https://imgur.com/a/WMoBTVN  ​

title: Desperate for promotion?
self_text: I'm currently working as a remote employee and I have ambitious goals. At this point, I'd like to move from an individual contributor to a managerial role. I talked to my manager about it and they said "just be good at your current role", and "we will check" to see how we can move you up a couple of months ago. Not sure how many times I've heard this in the past, only to be ultimately left hanging. Not saying that I will have the same outcomes as my previous managers who told me the exact same thing, but probably I have a tough time trusting these lines anymore without any immediate action/progress to my goals.  Now I'm thinking to message one of the company's exec who appears to be approachable (I've exchanged some emails with them when I was completing a project), to see their perspective as they have more influence. For context, the exec is 2-3 lines higher than my manager. Maybe somewhere along the lines of - to ask if they offer a "leadership rotational program" or plan to offer one in the future, or an internship to an open role where I can move up to a role with more influence. Will it do bad more than good for me in this scenario? Any peeps who had done the same and had quite some success rate?

title: How does tax work if I am a university student on placement
self_text: Hello so I am a university student who is on a year long placement. I started in June and I get paid 19,000 for the year. I get taxed around ¬£200 (income and NI tax) , I know I am entitled to ¬£12,570 tax free income so this means the remaining  ¬£6430 gets taxed.  My question is : How does this work? I have been getting taxed since I started so shouldn't I be getting my monthly pay checks tax free until 8 months into my job as this is when I pass the 12570 tax free income threshold?  Am I able to call up HMRC and get this tax money and change it to where I get taxed once I pass the  tax free income threshold or do I have to call them up at the end of the tac year?

title: If any of you could have/have a personal assistant, what do you typically have them do for you that makes your life easier?
self_text: So things have gotten pretty busy in my life: I run an educational nonprofit (where I have to make video content for my students - very, very much like running a small business), work a day job as a senior software engineer, and am interested in starting a venture on the side next year with some 3D modeling stuff. Managing all of it has become such a hassle that I've been recommended several times to get a personal assistant. But while I know one would be game-changing for me, I'm kind of at a loss for what I could even ask them to do (I suuuuuck at delegating tasks, but I'm trying to learn).  As a business owner (or just generally super busy person) what tasks would you have a personal assistant handle for you? I hear there are personal assistants that can even copywrite or video edit too, but I'm trying to remember that I may not be able to find someone that can do it all.  I'm asking this questions in a few subreddits related to the tasks that I have in the hopes of coming up with a comprehensive list so I can pick and choose whats most important to me, and settle on a list of tasks to assign them when I do find a good one.  If you guys have an ideas for what they could do, it'd be super helpful!

title: How is it legal to charge a cancelation fee that totals the rest of the yearly subscription?
self_text: I was made to purchase an Adobe creative cloud subscription for some of my classes this semester. I ended up never using the adobe programs and am looking to cancel the year long subscription I had to buy. I have been making monthly payments and now that I'm trying to cancel, Adobe is trying to charge me what would be the rest of the years monthly payments, as an "early cancellation fee" how is this legal and how can I get out of it? I am a college student and those $90 dollars could be used elsewhere much more important.

title: What Would You Pay For A Hoodie Or T-Shirt?
self_text: I've been debating starting a website or business that sells anime-related hoodies or t-shirts and I would sell the hoodies for about $40-$50 with free shipping of course and t-shirts I would probably sell for anywhere between $20-$30 but I'm not quite set on the pricing yet. In your honest opinion, what would you pay for a hoodie or t-shirt with a design of your liking?

title: Are there any alternatives to buying a health insurance plan on the marketplace if you don't get coverage through your employer? (USA)
self_text: My state marketplace only offers a handful of options which are all very pricy "gold" or better plans that I don't need. I don't want to skip out on insurance just in case something horrible happens, but the premiums are so expensive. Is there some other way to get coverage?

title: Does anyone trade with leverage here?
self_text: I'm a guy who likes taking risks, and firmly believes in high risk high return (so basically a gambler). And whenever I trade leverage I feel scared and exited at the same time. The moment I enter a position and watch the chart draw out its graph I'm at an immense state of nervousness. As the price fluctuates I feel like my heart beat also fluctuates. Mind you, I only trade with 25x or above, no pussy scaredy cat trading. Everytime I see that +50% profit after entering a position for 10 minutes, I feel like passing out due to overwhelming joy. Even A 1% price change to me is like having an insane bull run, or a bear run. The more trades I do I sense myself getting number to profits and losses. Do I need to stop? Should I stay away from crypto at this point? I've only lost 2 grand so far but I'm scared I might lose more

title: $AMZN, good trade and bade trade, but still in profit.
self_text: $AMZN  The stock opened with a small gap down, my first idea was to take the stock from a resistance level created in the last few days at $94 together with the descending trend line with a target at $92.3.  The trade was unsuccessful, and the stock took me out with a stop after twenty seconds of my entry.  I knew it was not the right timing and my idea was still valid so I continued to follow the stock, after a few minutes the stock stopped at the $95 resistance level and continued to fall to $94, broke the level, and consolidated below it, I entered orders:  Entry: $94  Stop loss - $94.37  Take Profit Point - $93.27 (2:1 RRR) I identified a level after the losing trade from the pre-market and that is why $92.3 was not the take profit point.  https://preview.redd.it/s6f1tordtb1a1.png?width=2205&format=png&auto=webp&s=3ad2061c734b94ba59f2a124bdba6698025d97b8  https://preview.redd.it/nexkrordtb1a1.png?width=2205&format=png&auto=webp&s=9f52b13f52b0fb8b6b14e5916ac99fc6febd674a

title: My plays for the week.
self_text: Puts on AMC, despite its current stock price, amc in my opinion is an overvalued shit company that is headed to 1 dollar. That being said wallstreet will probably pump the stock upon earnings. Fear not, my puts expire mid December and I predict the company will fall to 4 dollars by that point.   Calls on LYFT then puts, my thinking here is that uber did well on earnings. I think the stock will spike and then slowly fall later on.   Calls on DO, do is a small oil company. Oxy earnings, plus midterms will probably make oil go up.   Puts or Calls on RBLX, haven't really decided here but im leaning towards puts.   Im overall down 50% for the year, so don't mistake my regarded investment ideas for good advice. Goodluck lads.

title: Thinking about accepting a lower maternity cover position after being laid off. Will that mess up my future earnings based on lowering my pay?
self_text: So I was recently laid off from an executive position at my company. I‚Äôll be able to receive my current salary through most of Jan WARN act) and I‚Äôm going to get some severance which is great. My spouse  also works and if we cut our expenses some we can probably cover our family expenses through summer before needing to dip into our emergency fund (if no additional emergencies arise).   I have a really great opportunity come up in a similar niche industry for a maternity cover position but it‚Äôs for a position lower than my current position and the company is known for paying less than my previous employer. I like the idea of a temp position because I feel very competent I can do the position and I‚Äôve been working 15 years in an industry with grueling hours and a bit of break with an option to be hired on if a full time position becomes available sounds like a nice less stressful option. Should I take this lower position and salary instead of holding out for a better opportunity for potentially more money? If an opportunity does open up at this new company I think I will have lowered the rate I could negotiate which would suck. I‚Äôve made it a point to try to negotiate every job I‚Äôve ever had and for the most part have been able to get more money and I feel like I‚Äôm going to lose that pay history and leverage by taking this new temp job. The new environment sounds less stressful and the team sounds great but I hate the idea of lowering my pay history which I‚Äôve worked really hard to establish. Thoughts?

title: Is it better do buy USDT on Binance and send it to KuCoin since the prices aren't the same?
self_text: Hey guys, I'm new to this Cryptoworld so I need some help to decide exactly what to do. I recently opened an account at Kucoin exchange but they are charging me 5.23 BRL for each USDT on my current quotation, but when I search the USDT/BRL on Binance it's 5.09. Is it right? Because that's a lot of money for me since it's like I'm giving up of a USDT every 250BRL I deposit. If yes, that means it's worth it to do arbitrage between those exchanges?  Am I being dumb and not reading the right prices? Lol  ​  TYIA, I appreciate you help

title: Security deposit
self_text: I moved into my apartment in July of this year and signed a year long lease. I put down two months worth of security ($2,400). However, shortly into my new lease I found out that I FINALLY got accepted into public housing (after years of waiting) I gave my landlord 2 months of notice that I would be leaving.  My landlord is threatening to keep all of my security deposit. Is this legal?  There has been no damage to the apartment and I‚Äôm having it cleaned before moving.   Thanks for the input!
